dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE ON apartment doorway. As it opens and an  enormously SWEET-FACED, ELDER WOMAN steps out, bungled up against the cold -- turning back to call inside to the  unseen love of her long life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just going to get some  flowers, dear. I'll be back in  twenty minutes. It's tulip season  today. I'm so happy. And now she turns and faces the hallway... her sweetness  dissolves in a flash... replaced by repulsion and that  quickly she has reversed herself and re-entered her  apartment... closing the door as we consider her vacated.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN UDALL
dialogues.text: in the hallway... Well past 50... unliked, unloved,  unsettling. A huge pain in the ass to everyone he's ever  met. Right now all his considerable talent and strength  is totally focused on seducing a tiny dog into the  elevator door he holds open.

You ever watch  someone who doesn't know you're  watching...  an old woman on a bus,  kids going to school and you see  this flash come over them and you  know immediately that it has  nothing to do with anything  external -- that it's in respond  to a private thought they just  had? They are just sort of realer  and more alive. And when you  notice it so are you. If you look  at someone long enough, you  discover their humanity. Vincent's slack-jawed expression changes. He feels an  intellectual tingle to be having this conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know exactly what you mean. There's a joy in him at this moment -- a bit of purity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold it. Vincent does so -- hums a bit of "Satisfaction" to  celebrate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol and LESLIE, another waitress, are waiting for their order at the cappuccino bar. Leslie is telling the story  of the traumatic audition which may have turned her life. Carol is rapt. As they pass Melvin she does not break stride, nor give  him notice. Though she is aware of him -- resentfully so  -- hard not to be since he is giving a moment to moment  commentary on her every action.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clippity clop -- clippity clop --  she has to pretend she doesn't  hear me. Listening to the story  from the upset friend...  now she  drops off the cappuccino and  smiles at the putzette who doesn't  even say, "Thank you." No, the  putzette wanted the whipped cream  so back she goes and now she has  to pass him again and it's getting  tougher to make believe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reluctant forgiveness)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Melvin stops -- she passes behind him to deliver an  uncharacteristic rabbit punch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's with the plastic picnic  ware? Why not try ours...  afraid  it isn't clean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see the help -- judgement call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just give yourself a little pep  talk. "Must try other people's  clean silverware as part of the  fun of dining out."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong with your son,  anyway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you care? Melvin just looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's gotta fight to breathe.  His asthma can just shoot off the  charts -- he's allergic to dust  and this is New York and his  immune system bails on him when  there's trouble so an ear  infection...  Is this bothering  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (caught)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An ear infection can send us to  the emergency room -- maybe five,  six times a month where I get  whatever nine-year-old they just  made a doctor. Nice chatting with  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spencer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spence. She exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The greenhouse studio is a busy sanctuary, as Simon puts  the finishing touches on his painting of Vincent. A beat  and then a strange figure crosses between the CAMERA and  the scene -- gone before we can examine him further.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can put on anything you want  now. I might be sort of done  here...  Vincent quickly and expertly picks a CD to meet his  immediate needs and puts it on -- dying a little at every second of silence during the transition... then LOUD  MUSIC PLAYS...  Vincent even GOOSING the VOLUME. Simon  does a take -- he gestures Vincent to take it down --  which Vincent does.

dialogues.speaker: APARTMENT
dialogues.text: where it is not clear that a robbery is in progress --  Vincent's two friends from the street sweeping all  objects into large sacks -- one of them, Doug, pauses  to look past the terrace to the studio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucky Vinnie -- he's a painting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUSIC PLAYS -- Simon cleaning up his stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you're practically finished,  huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes...  well, there's one more  stage -- trying to figure out if  it's any good. Simon sneaks a look at the canvas from another  perspective...  he focuses -- then the smallest shy nod  of self-approval -- he's finished. Vincent is desperate  to distract. CLOSE ON dog as Verdell awakens, stretches and pricks his ears. He moves quickly to the closed door and starts to  frantically scratch, attracting Simon's attention. As Simon keeps walking...  Vincent shoots over to the  canvas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait -- I want to see the  painting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a second -- he has to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please!! NO!!! Simon opens the door and Verdell shoots out like a  bullet. Vincent pauses before the painting and is thrown  to see his humanity captured -- to be "immortalized."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug and Evan are nearly to the front door as VERDELL  stops them with a vicious GROWL and BARK. Simon is distracted -- looking down at his pet so that he continues to walk toward Doug and Evan, not noticing  them -- Vincent, terribly afraid, appears behind Simon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Vincent)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter, sweetheart? He instantly stops. Shocked. Frozen. His eyes on the  stranger, Doug, looking at him. Now Vincent comes in.  Doug greets him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yo. Simon turns to Vincent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you doing this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. No. No. Hey, that painting  in there...  I just want to tell  you...  Now Evan appears holding a brass hat rack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Vincent)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing? Cruising him? And he uses the hat rack first as a spear, then as a  club, as the brief savage attack begins.

dialogues.speaker: ON VERDELL
dialogues.text: as he starts to go toward Simon and then scurries back in fear. The three attackers leave. Now silence. A single  BARK from VERDELL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A mass of OFFICIAL PEOPLE clutter the hall as a gurney is whisked down to the elevator. It's impossible to tell if  Simon is awake or dead. Melvin is standing against the  wall near his door a cop, RAY, interviewing him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. So you call 911 and don't  leave your name -- even a dumb  geezer should know that emergency  automatically pulls up your name.  How come you make a mistake like  that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How come you're pretending to do  cop work -- 'cause I don't think  you could find your ass if you  were spotted the hole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stunned)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just move on. No one here killed  him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, is he dead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ask him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We will if we can and if we can't,  we'll come back and ask you again  and again.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: Frank standing upset, anxious, holding a dog bowl, a  leash and VERDELL, who is more upset making pathetic  little CRYING SOUNDS. As we FOCUS BRIEFLY ON Verdell...  Frank is talking to th Sweet-Faced Woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been praying for him since I  heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I've got to get to the  hospital. If you could take the  dog just for tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Lord -- I've got all these  antique knick-knacks...  Or else  I'd be glad...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe if you kept locked in  the bathroom. No? Okay. Thanks. (as he turns away and she  closes the door he adds)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Old bitch...  Damn dog. A short laugh makes us realize that Melvin has witnessed  and enjoyed Frank's hostile mutterings...  VERDELL starts WHIMPERING as a pissed Frank approaches  his mugger:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're taking him...  yes...  you're  taking him -- this will clear the  books. One night. You want to  say "no" to me? Try...  because  I've never felt as nuts as I do  right this second. I almost want  you to try saying "no."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not saying nothing to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for looking after him. Frank pushes open the door to Melvin's apartment and  places Verdell inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUSIC IN: as Frank pulls the door partially closed to  block Verdell's escape. The music represents Verdell's state of mind -- trapped  in the apartment of the man who tried to kill him. We  STAY with the dog during the O.S. dialogue: As his head  turns in panic we see his various POVs as the dialogue  continues O.S.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, where are you going? You  can't do this. (calls after Frank)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't take a dog. (a confession)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody's ever been in here before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (threatening)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't want to mess with me  today. I'll figure something else  out tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melvin enters -- the dog cowers in the shadows. Now  Melvin sees him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're dead!! VERDELL STOPS -- gives Melvin wide berth -- slinking  along the far wall. Melvin finds Verdell's fear of him a  bit calming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't have dog food. And I  won't want dog food here. You'll  eat what we have. You'll eat what  we eat. Melvin exits. Verdell is in a major funk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melvin breaks two eggs over a large pile of prime chopped meat, sticks raw pieces of bacon into it and exits the  room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you touch anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Verdell cringing as his new master approaches -- MUSIC  CONTINUES ominously. Melvin sets the bowl down and  exits...  Verdell breathes excitedly though looking  alternately in all directions... his recent past making  him suspect this feast is a trick. He sniffs  cautiously -- then dives in -- GOTHIC MUSIC CHANGING on a dime TO SCORE his RAPTURE... from O.S. we hear the sound  of RUNNING WATER as steam escapes the bathroom -- then  MUSIC OUT -- as Melvin returns...  ignoring Verdell he  sits at the piano and his one key repeatedly. It's odd.  Verdell shifts his body so he is eating from the bowl  with his tail to Melvin. Then Melvin begins to play and  sing Monty Python's "Always Look On The Bright Side Of  Life," with its cheerful whistle refrain. Verdell looks  over with surprise and pleasure. But just as mood lifts  and warmth threatens, Melvin stops abruptly, turns out  the lights and exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put the solid red dots on three of  them and the hold blue dots on two  others...  Well, we're not going to  sell anything if they know we're  two weeks into a show and have no  sales. No, you can't reduce a  price at this stage...  We're in  free fall here. Any calls?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can see him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll meet you in there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Jackie enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How you doing, great one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't looked at myself yet. I  figured I could tell from your  reaction. He turns toward her. Much of his body -- taped -- his  painting hand wrapped. Simon's face is something of a  horror. Swollen, one savage discolored cut. We are into  yuccchhh...  The sight is a jolt. Jackie breaks into  tears...  sobs, actually.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That bad, huh? They share a helpless half-laugh -- then Frank appears in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, hey...  (as he sees him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haaa...  bad but temporary. The  nurses say it's much better than  you looked three weeks ago...  the  hand will come back...  they're  sure...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie, will you hand me the  mirror?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a small voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. She starts to hand him a large mirror from her purse --  then thinks better of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait, I have a smaller one. But he holds out his hand and she gives him the mirror -- he starts to look -- then thinks better of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, what's new anyway? How's  Verdell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sheepish)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your neighbor -- Udall -- is  taking care of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly alive and upset)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How could you do that? He'll hurt  him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I promise...  not a chance. I  own this guy. There was no one  else. I'm on the move too much.  Trust me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are very certain my dog is  okay...  because you have no  idea...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Your dog is fine, Simon. Simon holds the mirror poised for a moment of discovery,  then he takes a breath -- like someone about to dive  underwater. First a small, mumbled pep talk to himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, waiting gives the devil  time. Now! He quickly brings his hand up and looks at the mirror... he is startled -- the bottom drops out -- leaving him  awed by his misfortune.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my... Where'd I go? Ummmm?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AN ESTABLISHING SHOT FEATURING Verdell tied up in front.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melvin finishing a plate of eggs, bacon and sausage with  his plastic knife and fork. Carol looks totally beat as  she sets down a cup of coffee. Melvin is craning  periodically to keep an eye of his dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what are you doing with a dog?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suckered in. Set up. Pushed  around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not worried that someone  might take him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, not until now -- for  Christ's sake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay -- I'll sit here. He changes tables for the first time ever so that he can  keep an eye on Verdell. Carol is amazed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know he's a little dog. Next  time, if Bryan's not here, you can  bring him in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How old are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, please...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I had to guess by your eyes,  I'd say you were fifty. Carol looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And if I had to guess by your  eyes. I'd say you were kind. So,  so much for eyes. But as long as  you bring up age...  how old are  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quickly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Otherwise, you're not ugly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs out loud)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, pal...  I accept the  compliment, but go easy -- my  knees start a-knocking when you  turn on the charm full blast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's with the dark? He indicates the bags under her eyes by tapping his own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dawn patrol -- major dawn patrol.  My son had a full blown attack.  And this time, for extra fun, they  gave us the wrong antibiotics, so  I get him home...  She reaches for the plate of uneaten bacon -- he goes  nuts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No...  no...  leave it...  the  bacon's for the dog. She is jolted by the insensitivity of his interruption,  but he doesn't notice, turning, almost chatty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last week I was playing the piano  for him and he likes it, and so I  decide I'm going to make a little  joke...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You all set here? Melvin nods -- a bit frustrated about not being able to  finish his dog story. He pockets the remaining bacon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Melvin walks Verdell back home, we notice, perhaps a  beat before Melvin, a remarkably event. Verdell is  avoiding the cracks in the sidewalk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a beautiful day for our walk. Melvin slows -- observes the dog mirroring his behavior.

dialogues.speaker: ON VERDELL
dialogues.text: again carefully placing his paws to avoid a crack in the  sidewalk. Melvin laughs out loud -- puts on plastic  gloves hurriedly so he can lift the dog to eye level.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be like me, don't you be  like me. You stay just the way  you are because you are a perfect  man. I'm gonna take you home and  get you something to eat...  what  you love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (charmed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ohhh. I'd like to be treated like  that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (all smiles to Verdell)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go home and do some writing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melvin whaling away at his computer, reading to himself  with great satisfaction as he goes. Verdell sits at his chair, fascinated by the speed of his master's fingers on the keyboard. He reads his writing  aloud to the dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "He turned off the gas jets and  carried her outside. He kissed  her brow and when her eyes opened  and found him, he said, 'there are  easier ways to break a date.' She  laughed. The only sensible  ambition he had ever known was now  realized. He had made the girl  happy. And what a girl. 'You've  saved my life,' she said, 'you'd  better make it up to me.'" Exhilarated by his own words, he shuts down the machine..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing to Verdell)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Done! (playing with him some)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I hate the doggy...  yes, I  hate the doggy. He exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sixty-two books... done! As the dog goes shooting off to the kitchen we leave our  couple's play time for...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the rookie invalid awakens in precisely the same foul  mood he'd had on falling asleep. In the living room, the  maid, NORA, is talking with Jackie -- we catch only a few words as they review Simon's mounting pile of bills and  talk of how long Nora can stay on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank knocking on Melvin's door. He opens it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's Verdell doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a pain in the ass. As he looks over at the dog, Verdell trots over and,  without realizing it, Melvin smiles at him to Frank's  surprise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon's home. I was sort of  hoping you could keep the dog  until he's had a chance to think  and adjust...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (leaping at the chance)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's been five weeks...  another  few won't kill me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. He wants him back. He'll be  by tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (too loudly, weirdly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay by me. Frank exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melvin sits -- Verdell looks up at him. Melvin walks to  the door. He turns the lock... then checks that they are  locked...  checks again to make sure he turned them in th correct direction...  turns from the door...  then back t check once more. And again...  and again...  anguished,  until now he breaks briefly, the dog looking on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melvin opens the door -- looks at the scarred Simon in a  wheelchair and shudders...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's some face they left hanging  on you. You look like...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could you take it just a little  easy, Mr. Udall? A beat of silence as Melvin thinks whether to comply.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. Verdell...  sweetheart? (to Melvin)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the way, thanks for saving me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I called. I never touched you. I  didn't leave my name or nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not listening)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Verdell?

dialogues.speaker: ON VERDELL
dialogues.text: Totally weirded out...  hiding behind Melvin...  now Melv shifts and Simon and Verdell see each other...  Simon  smiles at the dog...  he is emotionally caught up in the  reunion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, sweetheart. Verdell isn't eager.

dialogues.speaker: ON SIMON
dialogues.text: The first gnawing pains of rejection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon pats his leg -- trying unsuccessfully to get  Verdell to approach him. Instead the dog goes to the  door and scratches at it. Jackie starts to pick the dog  up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Please, don't force him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to dog)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You little stinker. He's given  you everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Verdell's towel on the floor -- near his bowl.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Melvin's lips compress... he sits on the piano bench and  hits a few keys...  looks at Verdell's empty spot again.. there are those who "get the joke" -- Melvin is clearly  one -- he laughs suddenly and helplessly even as he feels the panic rise in him...  ...  all his painstaking success in keeping the lid on an now it threatens to blow for a reason he articulates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over the dog...  an ugly dog. It's hilarious. But now the humor detours. An actual  sob is choked back...  he gets up -- following a definite pattern across the room. He is conducting a small but  highest-stakes fight for survival. Momentarily a scared,  beaten middle-aged man -- he races out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melvin charging as fast as crack checks allow and then  turning into a building with a copper sign reading  "Grammercy Park Psychiatric Group."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Worst sidewalk in New York and  look where they put in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melvin bursts in on the psychiatrist and emits one word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Help!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you want to see me you will not  do this. You will make an  appointment...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Explain to me how you can diagnose  someone as "obsessive compulsive  disorder" and then act like I have  any choice in barging in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's not going to be a debate.  You must leave. The Doctor moves into the hallway, forcing Melvin to  follow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said you could help me --  what was that -- a tease?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can help you if you take the  responsibility to keep regular  app --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You changed the room around...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two years ago...  Melvin shakes his head -- as if things weren't bad enough he must go through a careful exercise noting every new  element before he's at all comfortable... as he studies  each object. The Doctor is professionally intrigued  despite himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I also regrew my beard...  but  you're not interested in changes  in me... so it's like I always  told you...  when it comes to  people you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shhhhhhh. I don't have this  mountain of available time...  I  got to get to my restaurant on  time. Do you know how hard it is  for me to be here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. (as Melvin starts  for the office)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More PATIENTS in the almost-crowded waiting room. Melvin  passes through -- visibly drawn and upset. He stops.  Eyes on them. Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to other patients)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if this is as good as it  gets? They look stricken. He exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he walks to his booth and sits down. Enormous relief.  CHERYL, a heavy-set waitress, reluctantly moves to his  table -- unseen by Melvin as he takes out his utensils  and arranges them. In a corner booth, four big TRANSIT  AUTHORITY POLICE are having a meal together. Cheryl  looks at his utensils.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the heck are those for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. No. Get Carol.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm filling in. We don't know if  she's coming back. She might have  to get a job closer to home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you trying to do to me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the heck do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, elephant girl, call her or  something...  just let her do my  one meal here. I'll pay whatever.  I'll wait. (as she doesn't  budge; he screams)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do it!!! The MANAGER comes over, gesturing to the table of police  that he can handle it. All attention is on Melvin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out. Be silent or leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be quiet. Just let me wait.  No problem. Get her here -- have  her get me two sausages, four  bacon, two eggs over easy and  coffee. I'm not a prick here --  I'm a great customer. This day is  a disaster. I can't handle this,  too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out immediately or there's  going to be trouble. Melvin looks at the police, sizes up the hopeless  situation and rises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's going to be trouble??? He walks toward the door as Cheryl and all the other  employees applaud his defeat. As he passes a BUSBOY near  the door he hands him 20 dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol's last name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Connelly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An uncomfortable Melvin sitting in the back of a taxi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A neighborhood in Brooklyn -- a community. Melvin, ever  the shark observer, looks from the cab to see slices of  community life -- MEN in front of a bar, PARENTS giving  their CHILD a ride on a mechanical horse outside a local  store -- two YOUNG WOMEN discuss dating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he exits -- RINGS the BELL and is BUZZED in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol opens the door just as he arrives on her landing.  She holds a container of ice, washclothes and a  thermometer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm hungry. (on Carol's astonished  look)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've upset my whole day. I  haven't eaten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing here? Melvin ignores the question, instead answering a charge  he had imagined she might make...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is not a sexist thing. If  you were a waiter I would still be  here saying...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you totally gone? This is my  private home...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am trying to keep emotions out of  this. Even though this is an  important issue to me and I have  strong feelings about the subject.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What subject? That I wasn't there  to take crap from you and bring  you eggs? Do you have any control  over how creepy you allow yourself  to get?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I do, as a matter of fact...  and to prove it I have not gotten  personal and you have. Why aren't  you at work? You're not sick --  you don't look sick... just very  tired and bitter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My son is sick, okay? Even saying the sentence, "My son is sick" pushes some  emotions toward the surface which are wasted on the crazy man at her threshold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about your mother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you know about my mother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hear you talk when I'm  waiting!!! She crosses to the sink to dump the ice. Melvin takes a  step inside. Spencer, seven and looking ill, walks into  the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, honey...  I'll be right  there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (uncomfortably)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How ya doing? Spencer just stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (miffed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should answer when someone  talks to you...  Carol eyes Melvin with disgust and disbelief then  emphatically gestures him to "clear out." Melvin backs  out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. There is a limit, Melvin,  and I can't handle you teaching  my son manners. She closes the door in his face, then walks to her son  and leads him back to his room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA MOVES TOWARD mother and son sitting on the edge of Spencer's bed. She holds a digital thermometer to his  ear. They both count down the seconds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are going to treat ourselves to  a cab ride.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: As Carol carries her young son through a class of  uniformed KIDS from a Catholic elementary school. She  spots Melvin about to enter a cab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melvin, wait! The school kids pick up the chant in unison.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melvin, wait! Melvin, wait!  Melvin, wait! He turns to face them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up, kids! They immediately obey as Carol approaches him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melvin...  give us a lift. We've  got to go see our friends at the  hospital. Melvin is thrown...  he pauses a beat...  then holds the  rear door open as Carol hustles the kid inside. The  maneuver puts the beet red, sweating Spencer at his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll ride up front. Cover your  mouth when you cough, kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they settle in and drive off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brooklyn Presbyterian Hospital,  please and quickly please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Carol enters the hospital.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling back)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I owe you three dollars. Melvin follows behind her as she carries her son...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah...  any chance you'll  get back to work today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (furiously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!!! Stay away from me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Verdell lies just inside the front door whimpering for  Melvin. Jackie sits across from Simon's wheel chair...   she has some index cards in her laps which she  occasionally consults and shuffles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel terrible that I have to...  Simon? Forget about the dog for a  second. Simon forces his attention to Jackie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. What are those cards?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a bit embarrassed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank's idea. He thought I should  have notes so I did this right...  maintained focus, didn't get  emotional and tried not to terrify  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (scared shitless)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terrify me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See, he's right. I need the  cards. (reading from cards)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon, you're broke.

dialogues.speaker: VERDELL
dialogues.text: as their conversation continues -- the dog is distressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The medical bill are 61 thousand  now. I've spoken to your parents  and they didn't hang up or  anything -- they just said they  would feel strange calling you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I can't reach them. Verdell walks out on the terrace and looks off. He turns  for:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Verdell)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here, baby...  what is it,  Verdell?...  You miss the tough  guy...  (trying to be  Melvin-like)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, here I am, you little pissant  mop, happy to see me? How about  another ride down the chute? Oh,  God...  I don't mean it,  sweetheart...  (on Jackie's look)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I know...  Verdell hides behind a chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank loves you. You know that...  but I've spoken to him and he  feels that -- (reading from card)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- as a businessman, with limited  resources...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be able to keep my apartment  and studio, won't I?...  Just tell  me. As Jackie looks at him then thumbs for a card.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (overwhelmed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow...  Verdell has come near him -- he reaches out a hand to pet the dog and the dog ducks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is trying to write. He can't. His world has been upset He walks away from his work -- a highly unusual act. He  is distressed -- and then an idea and he exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are looking at ZOE, the receptionist. She is listening with interest to an O.S. conversation while answering  phone calls, "Premier Publishing."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, you write more than anyone  else. Yes, you make us a lot of  money, but isn't there someone  more appropriate to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need this. Just say, "Melvin,  I'll try," okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (resigned)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melvin, I'll try. They appear now -- the woman tall, attractive, etc. She  pauses at the elevator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, on a pleasant note, our son  got accepted at Brown. My  husband...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (curtly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great, wonderful. I don't need  you to wait with me. She nods, pissed, waves and leaves. As Melvin waits, Zoe  summons her moxie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't resist. You usually move  through here so quickly and I have  so many questions I want to ask  you. You have no idea what your  work means to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's it mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That somebody out there knows what  it's like to be...  (taps her head and heart)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: in here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh God, this is like a nightmare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw come on, just a couple of  questions -- how hard is that? As he hits the button, wipes his fingers, hits the button etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you write women so well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as he turns  toward her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think of a man and take away  reason and accountability. The fan is jolted as the elevator doors open and close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A depleted, exhausted Carol approaches her home. She is  suddenly wary -- SOUND DIALED DOWN -- as we MOVE CLOSER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A car at the curb with "MD" license plate.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: As Carol breaks into a run.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she bounds the stairs, comes to her apartment door and jiggles with the keys, a strange prescient whimpering  sound coming from her. As she enters the apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Connelly, I'm in here. The worst confirmed, she moves down the narrow hallway,  her innards squirting the same chemicals that drives elk  on opening day of the hunting season.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Please? Now? Tell me?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Connelly. I'm Martin Bettes ...  Dr. Bettes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not your name...  what are you  telling me your name for!! Where  is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's in the bathroom...  He's fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (overlapping)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me how bad it is. I let him  go out last night when it was so  cool without an overshirt -- just  and underone with just the straps  and I know better...  and I let him  talk me into it. He was whining  and...  you don't need this. Give  me a second to catch hold. And so she does. Wow does she... and gives us some  notion of the size of her fear demon and the strength it  takes to subdue it as Dr. Bettes keeps reassuring her and she keeps nodding... finally a deep breath as Spencer  enters from the bathroom. All at hyper speed now.  Salvation as farce.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to his mother)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi...  (they kiss)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you know there are doctors who  come to your house?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I didn't. (to Bettes)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So why are you h...  Beverly, Carol's mother, enters the room. She is ebullien which, if life allowed, would be her natural state.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't know you had a secret  admire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You met the gift.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's good...  And I'm an expert on  doctors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Spencer)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay out of this...  Doctor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My wife is Melvin Udall's  publisher. (as Carol reacts)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She says I have to take great care  of this guy because you're  urgently needed back at work.  What work do you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a waitress. ON Dr. Bettes' reaction her mother adds a saving grace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In Manhattan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Bettes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In here. A NURSE enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry it took so long. I don't  know Brooklyn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay, Terry. (hands her blood  vail)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell the lab I'd like the report  back today. Carol and her mother exchange a look of incredulity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're going to get the results  today?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As we approach the doctor and Carol seated across from  each other at a small table... soft voices...  relaxation Bettes is examining medicine bottles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long has he been having  problems?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since forever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have they done blood tests on him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only in the emergency room or when  he was well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emergency room only.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have they done skin testing for  allergies?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They haven't done the standard  scratch test. Where they make  small injections into the skin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I asked. They said it's not  covered under my plan. And it's  not necessary anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's amazing these things weren't  done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fucking H.M.O. bastard piece of  shit...  I'm sorry...  forgive me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Actually, I think that's  their technical name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once the tests come back, is there  someone I can reach in your office  for the results?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me. My home number is on this  card.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His home number. Carol look at her mother -- they share a laugh. Beverly  has a hard time stopping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to doctor)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want some juice or coffee  or two female slaves?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Water...  Nobody told you it might  be a good idea to remove the  carpeting and drapes in Spencer's  room?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. She starts towards Spencer's room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have to do it this  second...  it's not dangerous or  anything. It's just something  that's advisable. Look, there's  a lot to be checked but...  Hey,  your son is going to feel a  good deal better at the very  least...  She pats his head...  Then embraces him with fierce  intimacy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doc!!! (then)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So listen, you gotta let me know  about the additional costs -- one  way or the other we'll...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're considerable. But Mr.  Udall wants to be billed. She takes this as a blow to the heart, stomach and groin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon practices walking using his cane. A tearstained  Nora hugs him good-bye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You poor, poor man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's use just one poor, okay?  Anyway, dear, thanks for  everything. Forgive my recent  crankiness and as soon as things  are on track again I'll call. She kisses him and starts for the door and suddenly a  sharp intake of breath -- she's forgotten something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's going to walk Verdell? Simon hadn't thought of this either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nora holding her things, knocks on Melvin's door. Melvin  opens the door. Nora is still sniffling. He misinterprets

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is he dead yet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! Would there be any way for  you to be willing to walk his dog  for him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Absolutely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not just today -- Uh, could you  do it -- until, until he gets  back on his feet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a wonderful man. Two  o'clock is a good time. Here's  the key in case he's asleep. Open  the curtains for him, so he sees  God's beautiful work and knows  that even things like this happen  for the best.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where'd they teach you to talk  like this -- some Panama City  "Sailor want to hump-hump bar"?  Or was today getaway day and your  last shot at his whiskey. Sell  crazy some place else -- we're all  stocked up here. He closes the door in her face. She stands there...  thrown by the abruptness -- then lifts the two paper  shopping bags holding her things -- walks back toward the elevator -- pausing briefly outside Simon's door -- then  continues on her way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doctor gone, mother and daughter arguing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a seriously goofy man  behind this. You are not allowed  to block out that fact.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you really want to go back to  the runt doctors in Emergency who  keep telling us they can't help?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It lets a crazy man into our  lives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on. Why fight when we know  how it will come out. This isn't  like stocking or a string of  pearls. You don't send this one  back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shades drawn. Simon is a wheelchair...  the PHONE RINGS.  He goes to answer... the phone across the bed so that  reaching for the phone is a brief but difficult  struggle... he grunts with pain, hope and anxiety as he  answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?...  yes...  sure...  finally,  huh? Why, "finally"? Because I  called you so many times. Maybe  20. (relief)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, boy...  I was hoping it was  something like that. You didn't  get one of them, huh? 'Cause I  mean it wasn't only your office --  it was your home, hotel and the  cigar club you like in San  Francisco. No -- Sarcastic...  Of  course. I believe you. No, don't  fire anyone...  Please. Maybe I'm  wrong about the 20 times. Take a  breath...  (more)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, you miss me a little? Hey,  strike the question -- How's the  case going? Really. Fantastic.  I didn't hear. I haven't been  watching. Great. Just great.  I'm so happy. Whoopie! Me?  Well, I'm mending. No, I look  fine. Well, some of the damage  might still be noticeable if you  look closely...  He runs a hand across his scarred and still bloated and  beaten face...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carl, I need some help and you're  the logical one to turn to. (aghast)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! Not 'cause I blame you for  what happened. I hardly get how  you can ever think that. No, I'm  not being sarcastic. (trying to figure it  out)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess because you hired the guy  who did this you think...  No, I am  a sarcastic person. Well, if  you must know, the reason I said  you were the logical person is  because you always told me how you  thought I was this great person  who made you feel good about  humanity and everything. You do  remembering saying that? Well, whew.  Okay, so Carl. I hate asking but  this money thing is ridiculously  serious...  He picks up an index card from his night stand and takes  the leap -- reading the text he prepared in advance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Will you please loan me money? I  will pay you back. I will give  you whatever percentage of my  income I don't absolutely need  until I do. It will take a while.  But I don't know what I'll do if  you say"... that. (as he listens)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand...  yes...  No, I do. (a bit of boldness)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you know, you know -- you  didn't even ask how much, Carl?  Well, Frank has no right to  discuss how much I'm in hock...  no, you're right -- not the point.  So...  what have you been up to???  Uh-huh... Oh, the group show...   how was it? Well, I'm not  surprised that there's that much  talent around...  great...  Look --  gotta go...  no, you shouldn't feel  that way at all...  take care, you,  too...  you, too...  Good-bye. (as he hangs up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pal o' mine. It's very quiet.

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: A lonely figure -- who now holds his good hand up to his  face and appears on the verge of enormous emotional  release -- CAMERA MOVES TOWARD him as if to rendezvous  with the moment of catharsis...  ...  but Simon is denied even this small luxury as the  CAMERA ABRUPTLY ADJUSTS just as he begins sobbing to  focus on the door opening and Melvin and Verdell entering the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I'll bring him some food by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you for walking him. Simon wheels away from Melvin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you'll excuse me I'm not  feeling so well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It smells like shit in here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That cleaning woman doesn't...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, just leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are all your queer party  friends?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (his first shout)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out. Melvin pauses -- Simon weeping... Verdell looks at Simon  with concern. Melvin is thrown. Moved?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing worse than having to feel  this way in front of you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nellie, you're a disgrace to  depression.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rot in hell, Melvin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No need to stop being a lady...  quit worrying -- you'll be back on  your knees in no time. Simon swings his arm and cast at Melvin -- the sudden  attack jolts Melvin but not as much as what follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this fun for you? Well, you  lucky devil...  It just gets better  and better. I am losing my  apartment and Frank wants me to  promise to paint hotter subjects  and to beg my parents, who haven't  called, for help... and I won't.  And I don't want to paint anymore. Melvin has made for the door...  Simon blocks him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So the life I was trying for is  over. The life I had is gone and  I am feeling so damn sorry for  myself that it is difficult to  breathe. Right times for you --  huh, Melvin. The gay neighbor is  terrified...  (a sudden screamed  word surprises them  both)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terrified...  Lucky you, you're  here for rock bottom...  me  wallowing in self-pity in front of  you, you absolute horror of a  human being...  As Simon works to stop crying, Melvin is weird with  discomfort.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'll do one thing for you  that might cheer you up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't piss on a gift, tough guy.  You want to know why the dog  prefers me...  it's not affection.  It's a trick. Simon looks up, his mood turning on a dime -- he's  rapt...  Melvin comes and stands by his wheelchair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I carry bacon in my pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pleased)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, my gosh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hands him bacon)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now we'll both call him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, sweetheart...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yo, yo, yo...  Verdell goes like a bullet to Melvin... who is totally  surprised and staggered by the implications. True love  and such.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you leave now, please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stupid dog. (to Simon)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't get it. He exits...  looking apologetically at Simon in stoic  ruin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol in bed on the pullout sofa...  She is in turmoil... there is THUNDER, but no rain. She walks to the kitchen.  She is trembling as she drinks a glass of water and exits

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is on an air shaft and this is where Carol  shares a closet with her mother, who is now asleep. Carol quietly extracts a dress from the closet, leaving  her nightgown on the floor. There is something sexy  here, the woman in Carol churning. She plops on a summer  dress -- no time for underwear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol seeing a bus and dashing after it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol crossing to Manhattan. She looks as if she's on  her way to some final exam where she has no notion of the subject.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT, (RAIN)
dialogues.text: Hot summer night as she gets off the bus and now the  rains come...  We are in a familiar neighborhood.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN AND SIMON'S APARTMENT HOUSE
dialogues.text: As Carol consults the slip of paper with the address on  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she enters building and realizes it's not just that  she's wet -- the thin summer dress is a winner in any wet T-shirt contest...  the fabric clinging to her breasts,  like the old movie poster of The Deep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Carol passes Simon's door...  stands in front of  Melvin's apartment -- twists herself to ease nervousness  and knocks on the door...  then RINGS the BELL. Finally  Carol hears MUFFLED THROAT CLEARING on the other side  of the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, Udall?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol the waitress?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. As we hear him unlock the door, Carol looks at her  breasts and gasps. She grasps the fabric and holds it  straight out just as Melvin opens the door. His hair is  static city, standing on end as he periodically gives it  self-conscious pats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doctors had your billing  address. I'm sorry about the  hour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was working...  can't you just  drop me a thank-you note?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not why I'm here...  (tearing suddenly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  though you have no idea what  it's like to have a real  conversation with a doctor about  Spencer...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very uncomfortable)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Note. Put it in the note.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did yo do this for me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To get you back at work so you can  wait on me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you do have some idea how  strange that sounds??? I'm  worried that you did this  because...  She pauses -- the beginning of an extraordinarily long  silence. Finally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You waiting for me to say  something? (as she shakes her head)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What sort of thing do you want?  Look, I'll be at the restaurant  tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think I can wait until  tomorrow. This needs clearing up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What needs clearing up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (strong and true)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not going to sleep with you.  I will never, ever sleep with you.  Never. Not ever. Melvin's reaction? Well, he'll never get credit for the  brief but intense inner struggle -- the struggle not to  scream -- -- not to cry -- to process the sudden and stunning hurt  during his half turn away from her -- and then answer  hoarsely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. We don't open for the  no-sex oaths until 9 a.m. Carol is amused, surprised...  maybe, in some small way  ever taken by his style...  but top priority is clarity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not kidding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay!!!! Anything else?!?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just how grateful I am. Her mission completed -- she turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you'll be at work?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a 3:22 a.m. as the two digital clocks on Melvin's  night stand tell us...  He gets up -- the first time we'v seen his waking routine -- taps one foot on the floor  twice -- then the other foot -- two more taps and his  body angles from the bed in a deliberate way. He is having anxiety. He sits at the piano and plays  very briefly...  Stops -- wipes some sweat from his  forehead...  Walks to his computer room -- turns the ligh on and then quickly off...  Walks to his refrigerator...

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: As he grabs a cardboard take-out box...  INT. NEW YORK APT. BUILDING - HALLWAY/SIMON'S APT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He knocks of Simon's door...  It opens quickly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I took a chance you were up. Simon walks painfully back to a chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I brought you Chinese soup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have never been so tired in my  life. Okay, if I sit here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got any easier questions? Melvin sits and moans -- the dog sitting near him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't been sleeping. I  haven't been clear or felt like  myself. I'm in trouble. Some son  of a bitch is burning my bridges  behind my back...  But the  tiredness -- boy...  Not just  sleepy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But sick -- nauseous -- where  everything looks distorted and  everything inside just aches --  when you can barely get up the  will to complain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (brightening)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah...  He feels a touch of community and not knowing where to  take it from here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm glad we did this. He rises and makes an awkward exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good talking to you. He exits -- Simon puzzled and concerned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol seated working on a letter... She is trying to  express her gratitude... An enormous sheaf of completed  pages sit next to her... She is so involved she doesn't  even look up as a young man, SEAN, knocks on the door and is let in by Beverly. They exchange greetings and move inside where we faintly  hear Spencer greeting him... We MOVE IN and read over  Carol's shoulder -- "I'm sorry to have gotten sloppy and  emotional in this letter, but it would have been on my  conscionce (sic) forever if I didn't tell you how  gratefull (sic)... "

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not still writing that  thank-you note?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm on the last page. How do you  spell conscience?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C-o-n-s-c-i-e-n-c-e. I got Sean  from the bakery to baby-sit so  let's go out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I still don't feel safe leaving  Spencer with someone. How do you  spell it again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spencer is okay. You'd better  start finding something else to do  with your free time. If you can't  feel good about this break and  step out a little...  (struts and pumps  her arms)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ought to get Mr. Udall to send  you over a psychiatrist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (more emotionally  than she intended)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't need one 'cause I know  what's really going on here. I  have to finish this letter or  I'll go nuts. (looking at paper;  weepy)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This can't be right -- con- science. Carol breathes heavily -- gets control, stopping herself  on the brink of crying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol. What? Carol is amazed at herself... that she might not be able  to stem the flow... wide-eyed with apprehension, she  looks at her mother, who, in return, only nods permission for Carol to let it go. A last defiant snort from Carol  -- and then she is overwhelmed. The headline comes first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know... It's very strange  not feeling that stupid panic  thing inside you all the time.  Without that you just start  thinking about yourself -- and  what does that ever get anybody.  Today, on the bus there was this  adorable couple and I felt myself  giving them a dirty look -- I had  no idea everything was...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (great, forceful  hand gestures)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... moving in the wrong  direction... Away from when I  even remembered what it was like  to have a man to... anything...  hold fucking -- sorry -- hands  with, for Christ's sake. I was  feeling like really bad that Dr.  Bettes is married. (this next one's  tough)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which is probably why I make poor  Spencer hug me more than he wants  to... Like the poor kid doesn't  have enough problems. He has to  make up for his mom not getting  any. (weeps at her  insight)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, boy. Who needs these  thoughts?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spencer's doing fine. So what are  you saying, that you're frustr...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave me be! Why are you doing  this? Why are you picking at my  sores... What is it that you  want?... You want what? What's  with you? I hope getting me  thinking of everything that's  wrong when all I want is to not  do this has some purpose. (puffy; red;  furious)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it, Mom? No kidding. Slumped, fought out -- Carol gets out one last, naked  husky voiced question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it you want? What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want us to go out. A beat, then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (simply)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they enter, still wiping away the effects of their  cry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Sean)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're going out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at their  red eyes)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like fun. She kisses Spencer -- almost getting involved in what  he's doing -- then sees her mother waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay -- we're out of here. I love  you. Spencer nods -- involved with Sean. CAMERA FOLLOWS Carol  as she exits the apartment -- her mother leading.  Halfway down the stairs, she stops and reverses herself,  going back to the apartment which she re-enters -- then  to her son to ask:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you love me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. Carol exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beverly and Carol walking past the store windows. A  simple and unprecedented experience in their recent  lives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice to get out, isn't it? Carol nods tightly... then they wrap arms around each  other and continue walking, turning into a corner bar.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: As Carol stands nervously while Lisa finishes reading her 14-page letter. In the b.g. Melvin and Frank are seated  at the same table and in earnest conversation. Lisa  keeps flicking away tears -- a few drops on the pages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't get it wet. Lisa brushes the paper -- finishes and embraces Carol.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So it's okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You almost have me liking him.  You sure come from the heart. I  never knew what you went through  with everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted him to know how much he'd  done. (looking over)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you believe he's eating with  someone. ON MELVIN & FRANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not my dog and this Simon  seems to have enough on his mind  -- but he did throw up twice and  his spark is off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure -- take him to the vet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did. And his stomach is out of  whack. So they need him for a  couple of days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melvin. She self-consciously hands him with the thick envelope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sotto)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A thank-you note for what you did  for me. He hands it back to her deliberately. She takes it and  walks back to the service area where, embarrassed,  confused, and messed with -- she tosses the note. After Carol leaves...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Frank)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really nice. Shouldn't that be a  good thing... telling someone,  'no thanks required.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It looks like it really went over.  You're sure making the rounds.  Simon says you brought him soup  last night. I hope he doesn't  write you a note. Melvin looks up -- wary -- his brain sends a disturbing  message.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "What?" Look at you... You sense  a mark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey -- you called me... I...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About a dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but it's all about Simon  now... you helped with the dog...  And now there are other things.  I'm just as concerned as you are  about Simon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Concerned. I'm just the hall  monitor here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not only financial  assistance. What he's got to do  is go to Baltimore tomorrow and  ask his parents for money. It's  not going to happen on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. If his parents are alive  they've got to help -- those are  the rules. Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. And tomorrow? I have a high  maintenance selling painter coming  through... So I'm out. Can you  take him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think white and get serious. Carol enters scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take my car -- a convertible. Do  you drive?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (loudly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like the wind but I'm not doing  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Getting loud, getting loud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wants me to take his car and  his client to Baltimore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want your life for a minute  where my big problem is someone  offers me a free convertible so I  can get out of this city. She exits. Frank prepares to depart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. I'll take him. Get him  packed -- ready -- tomorrow  morning. Frank stumbles back... self-satisfied, he relaxes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (excited)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay... so I'll see you tomorrow.  Let's not drag this out. We don't  enjoy another that much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If there's some mental health  foundation that raises money to  help people like you be sure to  let me know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last word freak. Frank adjusts and exits... Carol approaches calling a  "good-bye" to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So. Anything else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I'm going to give my queer  neighbor a lift to Baltimore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, what I did for you is working  out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a breath; then)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you did changed my life. She offers him the note.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No... no thank you notes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, part of what I said in this  entire history of my life which  you won't read is that somehow  you've done more for my mother, my  son and me, than anyone else ever  has... And that makes you the most  important, surprising, generous  person I've ever met and that you  be in our daily prayers forever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lovely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I also wrote one part... I wrote  I'm sorry... I was talking about I  was sorry when I got mad at you  when you came over and you told my  son that he ought to answer back  so I wrote that. (reading from the  letter, Melvin  wildly uncomfortable)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was sorry for busting you on  that... and I'm sorry for busting  in on you that night... when I  said I was never... I was sorry  and I'm sorry every time your food  was cold and that you had to wait  two seconds for a coffee filler...  Melvin wants to disappear but Carol is getting into it -- emotionally moved by her own words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... and I'm sorry for never  spotting, right there at the table  in the restaurant, the human being  that had it in him to do this  thing for us... You know what, I'm  just going to start from the  beginning... I have not been able  to express my gratefulness to  you... even as I look at the word  "grateful" now it doesn't begin to  tell you what I feel for you...  And finally Carol notes Melvin's mood and pauses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice of you... thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now I want you to do something for me. She looks at him for a very strange, long beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm sorry... Didn't I say,  "what?" I thought I said,  "what?"... What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to go on this trip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sir...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't do this alone. I'm afraid  he'll pull the stiff one eye on  me. I need you to chaperon.  Separate everything but cars. You  said you liked convertibles. Now  I'm on the hook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The stiff one eye?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't. I work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You take off when you have to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bettes tells me he's doing fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (no other way)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melvin, I'd rather not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that got to do with it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Funny, I thought it was a strong  point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Write me a note and ain't she  sweet. I need a hand and where'd  she go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you saying accepting your help  obligates me!?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there another way to see it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol takes an old weekend case down from the top shelf  of the closet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, here's a little suitcase  shocked that it's been used. She holds up a dress -- a pretty one... then decides it's too pretty and puts it back... Now she looks in another  drawer and pauses as if she ponders one of the mysteries  of the ages. She hesitates then talks to herself.

dialogues.speaker: UNDERWEAR DRAWER
dialogues.text: Her best underwear neatly stacked alongside her everyday  "girl Jockies." She fingers the good stuff -- puts it  back -- then the everyday -- hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (furiously exasperated)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's not way to pack for this  trip... well, I'll tell you -- I'm  not packing the camera. As she exits the room --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she picks up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melvin is in his bedroom -- everything he's taking neatly stacked on the bed waiting to be packed (he is taking a  camera). He has a list of what he needs. All items --  underwear, socks, etc... with four checks next to each  one and still he -- checks each stack on the bed and adds another check. The PHONE RINGS. This is an amazing  development. He has almost no recent experience with  receiving a nighttime phone call. He makes a little  comment to himself as he moves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Woo-woo. He stops -- briefly trying to remember where the phone is -- and then, remembering, crosses and picks it up but  before bringing it to his mouth nervously clears his  throat.

dialogues.speaker: ON CAROL
dialogues.text: As she hears his throat being cleared. It is not a  pretty sound. (The following conversation is INTERCUT.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you still coming?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Melvin visibly relaxes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melvin... I'd like to know exactly  where we are going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just south to Baltimore, Maryland.  So I know what you're going to ask  next. (correcting himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That you might ask -- I'm not  certain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's... there's no need to  bring anything dressy... or... I  mean -- I didn't know if we'd be  eating at any restaurant that  have dress codes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. (a beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We might. Yes. We can. Let's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, gotcha. What did you think  I was going to ask?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whether crabs are in season there  now...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Okay, then -- Melvin. Good  night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beverly looks up expectantly as her daughter enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How was it talking to him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop treating this like I'm going  away with a man. He's just going  to say those crappy, sick,  complaining, angry things to me.  I hate this, Mom -- I hate this.  He's a freak show -- the worst  person I ever met.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, maybe he has nice friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beverly and Spencer wait with her. The bus approaches.  She kisses them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Spencer)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You stand there and I'll wave to  you from the back window. As she boards the bus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call me as soon as you're settled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Spencer)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you. The bus driver closes the doors on her -- she shoves them open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to bus driver)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sensitive, huh?! The bus pulls out. He runs after the bus -- waving at  his mother who grows concerned that he might be taxing  himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A female VETERINARIAN in surgical scrubs holds Verdell as Melvin finishes filling out some forms. On opposite sides of the waiting room, a very large black dog and a tiny Chihuahua sit patiently with their owners.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything unusual in the dog's  diet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Everybody gets their own  cage?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certainly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing to  Chihuahua)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put him in with that one, not that  one...  (pointing to large  dog)
